verses.verse: (3 The people promise to obey God.4 Moses writeth the civil Laws.9, 13 Moses returneth into the mountain.14 Aaron and Hur have the charge of the people. 18 Moses was forty days and forty nights in the mountain.) Now he had (When he called him up to the mountain to give him the Laws, beginning at Exod. 20, hitherto.) said unto Moses, Come up to the Lord, thou, and Aaron, Nadab, and Abihu, and seventy of the Elders of Israel, and ye shall worship afar off.
And Moses himself alone shall come near to the Lord, but they shall not come near, neither shall the people go up with him.

¶ (When he had received these laws in mount Sinai.) Afterward Moses came and told the people all the words of the Lord, and all the (Hebrew, judgments.) Laws: and all the people answered with one voice, and said, (Cross references: : Exod. 19:8) All the things which the Lord hath said, will we do.

And Moses wrote all the words of the Lord and rose up early, and set up an (Exod. 20:24) altar (Or, at the foot of the mountain.) under the mountain, and twelve pillars according to the twelve tribes of Israel.
And he sent young (For as yet the Priesthood was not given to Levi.) men of the children of Israel, which offered burnt offerings of beeves, and sacrificed peace offerings unto the Lord.
Then Moses took half of the blood, and put it in basins, and half of the blood he sprinkled on the altar.
After, he took the (Or, the book of the Law.) book of the covenant, and read it in the audience of the people: who said, All that the Lord hath said, we will do, and be obedient.

Then Moses took the (1 Pet. 1:2; Heb. 9:20) blood, and sprinkled it on the people, and said, Behold the (Which blood signifieth that the covenant broken cannot be satisfied without blood shedding.) blood of the covenant, which the Lord hath made with you concerning all these things.
¶ Then went up Moses, and Aaron, Nadab, and Abihu, and seventy of the Elders of Israel.

And they (As perfectly as their infirmities could behold his majesty.) saw the God of Israel, and under his feet was as it were a (Hebrew, brick work.) work of a Sapphire stone, and as the very heaven when it is clear.
And upon the nobles of the children of Israel he (He made them not afraid, nor punished them.) laid not his hand: also they saw God, and (That is, rejoiced.) did eat and drink.

¶ And the Lord (The second time.) said unto Moses, Come up to me into the mountain, and be there, and I will give thee (Signifying the hardness of our hearts, except God do write his laws therein by his Spirit, Jer. 31:33; Ezek. 11:19; 2 Cor. 3:3; Heb. 8:10 and 10:16.) tables of stone, and the Law, and the Commandment, which I have written, for to teach (To wit, the people.) them.
Then Moses rose up, and his minister Joshua, and Moses went up into the mountain of God,
And said unto the Elders, Tarry us here until we come again unto you: and behold, Aaron and Hur are with you: whosoever hath any matters, let him come to them.
Then Moses went up to the mount, and the cloud covered the mountain,
And the glory of the Lord abode upon mount Sinai, and the cloud covered (Or, him.) it six days: and the seventh day he called unto Moses out of the midst of the cloud.

And the sight of the glory of the Lord was like (The Lord appeareth like devouring fire to carnal men: but to them that he draweth with his Spirit, he is like pleasant Sapphire.) consuming fire on the top of the mountain, in the eyes of the children of Israel.
And Moses entered into the midst of the cloud, and went up to the mountain and Moses was in the (Exod. 34:28; Deut. 9:9) mount forty days and forty nights.
